newsitem.title: USA: US debt managers boost corporate allocations - MCM.
newsitem.headline: US debt managers boost corporate allocations - MCM.

text.p: A majority of U.S. fixed-income managers overweighted corporate debt positions on their U.S. debt portfolios over the past week, an MCM MoneyWatch Inc survey said.
"Cash positions dropped sharply ... as money was put to work in last week's rally," said MCM MoneyWatch vice president Astrid Adolfson, who conducts the weekly survey.
Adolfson said the buying seemed to have been in corporates with 75 percent of the respondents showing an overweighted position.
The survey showed durations as a percentage of benchmark slipped to 108.1 percent in the week ending June 9 from 108.2 in the prior week.
A duration reading above 100 percent indicates the group of investors polled is mostly long on the market.
A portfolio's duration represents its average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.
In the "next likely move" category, portfolio managers representing 32 percent of total assets in the survey said they would "buy," compared with 37 percent the prior week.
Strategists leaning toward "sell" held steady at 12 percent.
Fifty-six percent of managers said they were "neutral" on the market.
Cash as a percentage of assets fell to 2.89 percent from 3.09 percent registered the previous week.

The survey showed 36 percent of investors polled overweighted the 10-plus years duration sector, higher from the 30-percent in the previous week, while 8.0 percent underweighted it. The remaining 56 percent were "neutral."
In the five- to 10-year duration sector, 43 percent of investors polled said they overweighted the securities and 11 percent underweighted them.
The survey included 38 domestic participants who manage about $110 billion in fixed-income assets. The poll is conducted weekly by MCM and usually is released on Tuesday.
